words.hint: Modern PHP framework for building structured and robust web applications.
A set of software tools and libraries that provide a ready-to-use structure for application development.
Architectural pattern separating responsibilities into three layers: Model, View, Controller.
Protocol that keeps PHP processes persistent to improve performance compared to CGI.
FastCGI Process Manager for PHP, responsible for interpreting requests and executing scripts.
The core of a Symfony application, responsible for initializing configuration, bundles, and services.
Principle of providing a class with its dependencies instead of creating them internally.
Human-readable data serialization language, used for Symfony configuration.
Template engine used in Symfony to generate HTML from .twig files.
Protocol for securing Internet communications through encryption.
Security protocol succeeding SSL to encrypt Internet communications.
Package manager for Windows used to install Symfony and other tools.
Function applied to a variable in Twig to transform its output.
An object-relational mapper that converts PHP objects into SQL queries and vice versa.
Doctrine component responsible for managing persistence and synchronizing entities with the database.
A file containing SQL instructions to create, modify, or delete tables and columns.
A Doctrine class used to retrieve data from the database using predefined or custom methods.
Doctrine Query Language, an object-oriented query language used by Doctrine to manipulate entities.
Mechanism that loads data only when it is actually accessed.
Symfony debugging tool displaying SQL queries, response time and other performance data.
Symfony component that converts a value from one format to another between form and entity.
Unique textual identifier, usually used in URLs to represent content.
Cryptographic transformation of a password into a non-reversible digest.
Source from which Symfony loads users (DB, LDAP, etc.).
Protection zone defined by URL pattern that encapsulates authentication and access logic.
Protection against cross-site request forgery using a unique token per form.
Class deciding whether to allow an action on an object based on business rules.
